Here the many new avenues of awareness opened into traditional fields and subjects would
be related to the new media since telegraph and photography. As William Ivins shows, for
example, in his Prints and Visual Communication, engraving created new possibilities for
science and mathematics from the fiteenth century onward. The basic power of the print or
engraving was exactly repeatable information. The 'network of rationality99 by which the
engraver captured the external world offered a means of statement and syntax which hastened
scientific advances. But with the photo the external world was captured completely, without
lines or syntax. Syntax disappears into "compostion" and lay-out. The same has happened
in mathematics and poetry and painting and music in our time.
Such a text would set up exercises of observation and analysis and a variety d means of
discussion which would bring into play all that the students have experienced of this
medium . This would in turn be related to other arts and media by detailed comparisons and
contrasts.
